title: Isolated Proximal Phalanx Fracture of the Right Index Finger in a Recreational Basketball Player
clinical_history: Jacob, a 28-year-old right-handed graphic designer and recreational basketball player, presented with acute pain, swelling, and decreased mobility in his right index finger after jamming it against another player’s hand during a game four days ago. Immediate swelling and bruising developed at the base of the index finger. He attempted to apply ice and self-splint with minimal relief. Jacob now reports difficulties with fine dexterous tasks at work, gripping objects, and notes increased pain with any attempts at active finger flexion or extension. There is no numbness or tingling; however, he is concerned about ongoing stiffness and the potential for long-term impairment.

nprs.affected_area: base of proximal phalanx of right index finger (primary site of fracture)
dorsal surface of right hand extending towards metacarpophalangeal joint (secondary, related to swelling and compensation)

aggrevating_factors: Attempted gripping, pinching, typing for prolonged periods, basketball activities, accidental bumping of hand. Active or passive motion, especially flexion-extension maneuvers.
picture: [insert image showing swelling and bruising at right index finger proximal phalanx, loss of normal finger contour]
easing_factors: Immobilization with finger splint, elevation, application of ice, limiting hand use, NSAIDs.
past_history: No prior hand or finger injuries. History of mild right wrist tendinitis two years prior, resolved with self-care.
medical_history: Generally healthy—no chronic illnesses. Updated tetanus immunization. No known allergies.
medications: Ibuprofen 400mg every 8 hours as needed for pain and inflammation.
personal_history: Lives alone, works full-time at a computer station. Regularly plays basketball, enjoys racquet sports recreationally. Non-smoker, occasional alcohol use.
imaging: Plain radiograph (AP/lateral views) shows a non-displaced transverse fracture of the proximal phalanx of the right index finger. No evidence of joint involvement or significant angulation.
